text: Last winter, I had the pleasure of composing a somatic exercise
speaker: Subject

text: with my friend ~C ~A Conrad
speaker: Subject

text: Our exercise was based on downtown New York City cellist Arthur Russell's masterpiece, World of Echo.
speaker: Subject

text: It is difficult to describe Russell's World of Echo for anyone who hasn't heard it before
speaker: Subject

text: It has a rare spiritual quality, which issues from Russell's songwriting, voice and cello playing, but also from the production values of the album
speaker: Subject

text: Perhaps the following passage from Tim Lawrence's biography of Russell, Hold Onto Your Dreams makes palpable Russell's subtle, accidental studio processes.
speaker: Subject

text: During these sessions it became standard for Arthur to splice together separate tapes
speaker: Subject

text: and he would regularly grab a track from one tape and fly it into the multitrack of another while his onlooking engineer tried to stay calm
speaker: Subject

text: Quote
speaker: Subject

text: We would be mixing on a piece of tape and I would see the splice go by, recalls Eric Liljestrand
speaker: Subject

text: It was all very confusing. I could never really tell what we were working on until it was done,
speaker: Subject

text: unquote
speaker: Subject

text: The ghostly accidents that arose from Arthur's insistence that they rerecord over old tape became= became an integral+ part of the sonic fabric
speaker: Subject

text: At one point, Conrad told me that he used the album to heal a knee injury that he had suffered
speaker: Subject

text: Russell was trained foremost as a musician and only afterwards as a Buddhist. So the healing powers of his music I can only imagine come from the confluence of these two disciplines.
speaker: Subject

text: For our exercise, Conrad and I decided to have Russell's album playing on four different stereos throughout the five story house for a twelve hour duration
speaker: Subject

speaker: Subject

text: Among the constraints I recall imposing on myself,
speaker: Subject

text: Interrupting myself mid line, then picking up with the line again

text: These exercises in intention and distraction I felt were true to Russell's music
speaker: Subject

text: So was a certain circularity that the exercises were trying to induce amidst interruption and disjunction

text: She went all over the world, weeping histrionically, tears on my pillow, far from home. Her lean militant form arched against the bleached s- s- stones of the pilgrimage site in Tunisia, while her head drooped with the weight of unrequited martyrdom. Her tall limbs charged with faith strode along the road to Canterbury, leaving the group of otherwise jovial companions on the road, in Rome and Rouen, ((short and on mien)) on the path to remoter sites along the Black Sea and into the sacred places of the Eastern Church. At eighteen she was pale, fierce, erect, prouder at twenty two. At thirty an iron maiden, resolute and commanding. At thirty seven, an intimidating force. At sixty, severe and twisted. text: In the fall of nineteen ninety seven, I moved into a two bedroom fat # flat, just up the street from my previous residence
speaker: Subject

text: though here everything was different.
speaker: Subject

text: Now I had one roommate instead of three, which meant I could occupy the living space less anonymously.
speaker: Subject

text: The reason I at times experience certainty that I started this book in the summer of nineteen ninety eight is that through the window of this new bedroom I saw my first concrete tree.
speaker: Subject

text: I was struck by what I thought was an anomaly until I began seeing this type of tree all over that unique city.
speaker: Subject

text: Within the first few sentences of the novella after that, you will find the concrete tree outside my window written quite simply.
speaker: Subject

text: {lipsmack} Years later, I would have to rewrite that passage as too many people unfamiliar with the concept, concrete tree, worried over its incongruous presence.
speaker: Subject

text: A few months ago, I addressed this concern by changing the text to, The trees outside my window are the first in ((a)) series of architectural leaps intended to beautify this city, these saplings protected by cylindrical holes of concrete
speaker: Subject

text: To those of you who also lived in this great cement city, I apologize for such an overt description, but there are certain things one cannot understand as o- # if one has never seen them.
speaker: Subject

text: For instance it never snowed in my previous city, the city of the novella, yet today it is late March in my new city and flurries blow past the window
speaker: Subject

text: I have called ((Chubby)) to tell her this and she sputters, What, what, wrapping her mind around the concept
speaker: Subject

text: This is what you do when you're editing, isn't it? You move text around, you delete something that does not have the anticipated effect on your trial reader. You write down somewhere that you have deleted that thing, then you put a question mark beside it
speaker: Subject

text: How many times have I been thrown into confusion when explaining to someone the cuts I've made, that person being different from the trial reader, and that person has responded with a violent shake of the head, pressing the point, I totally understand that. Put it back in
speaker: Subject

text: The number of times I have done that matches the number of times I have run to a nearby park, thrown myself on a bench and fallen over with my head in my lap, my hands scraping the ground with the smallest of smiles on my face.
speaker: Subject

text: Confusion is a gift, I have always thought
speaker: Subject

text: That is the reason for the smile
speaker: Subject

text: Similarly when I am in the midst of an overwhelming sadness, those moods that have no identifiable cause, I begin to marvel over the ability to have such feelings
speaker: Subject

text: I write something down, usually on a loose sheet of paper, thinking the feeling's too fleeting for my diary and give that smile again, buried in the typical frown of sadness.
speaker: Subject

text: Because what I've written is beyond me.
speaker: Subject

text: Eventually, one comes to know what belongs in a book one is writing and what does not and eventually one changes one's mind on all of this
speaker: Subject

text: I finished the final version of the novella after that sometime late summer two thousand and three after two extensive rewritings and probably two less intense reworkings and countless line and paragraph edits, plus two shelvings and one almost utter shredding, and then I ran outside. The relief I felt was tremendous, though ultimately short lived+.
speaker: Subject

text: You have finished your novella, I told myself. You have made a place for it. I was in my new city when I said this
speaker: Subject

text: I had changed cities because I could not stand to see the demise of my old one, though I was aware that I had been living in its entrails for some time.
speaker: Subject

text: But I do not think I need to reiterate my reasons for blinding myself to that reality. As it goes, I moved, many places at first then finally settled on this new one
speaker: Subject

text: Why am I here, I asked myself walking among its thousands of ghosts. I could not find an answer but in the interim I met a girl and became enamored with her. She will be referred to as ~M.
speaker: Subject

text: I showed the novella to ~M once she had read my other work and upon finishing it she said, Hm, studying me.
speaker: Subject

text: We were in a very large park. I think she turned her head to see if this park mirrored the one referred to in the novel. I didn't write it here, I explained it to her. She did not appear to believe me. Well, people will think what they want. It is their right, I suppose. But After That could never have been written in this city
speaker: Subject

text: I wrote it in a place of perpetual sun, a place that never rose above thirty degrees Celsius. I've given up Fahrenheit in protest of the government. It never sank below ten. A place of crowds that did not overwhelm one as they do here. A place whose incomparable ease explains the near flatness of the writing, this flatness which I could never alter and always haunted me.
speaker: Subject

text: That first summer in my new city, the sensation of my own flatness was very strong
speaker: Subject

text: With ~M in the park, I was struck by the persistence of it
speaker: Subject

text: this feeling which I thought had rid {NSV} # I had rid myself of by simply maturing as a person had never left me
speaker: Subject

text: It had just taken on another form, manifesting itself differently yet deep- deeper with every subsequent book
speaker: Subject

text: It+ strikes often at the end of the day when I'm reviewing some work I have just written and I find myself thinking that it is not writing that I have done. It is speech or air, plain air. It is zero. It is a gesture, a sign, an indication of writing, but not writing. Not at all writing.
speaker: Subject

text: Nowadays, I'm more or less content to let a lot of things take their own courses, like amiable rivers making blue lines down the map of history
speaker: Subject

text: I'm not saying that some things don't infuriate me. They certainly do. But I've learned mostly through stupid repetition the same patience I apply to my own works.
speaker: Subject

text: Moving them out of range of good and evil is applicable in a romantic way I guess to things natural and unnatural. Outside myself I'm on better terms though still able to bear grudges with most things and people, more social- socially amiable
speaker: Subject

text: no longer stand in a corner at parties facing into the wall, smelling the ((school like)) plaster getting plastered
speaker: Subject

text: Now I talk it up, and even when down, never talk down but remain subdued
speaker: Subject

text: I've learned to like winters more, but hate the end of ((same)) feel relief at spring, crave sun on body, enter through the lobby of annual depression, have greater sense of personal comfort, expanding horizons, ability to survive and know how far I'll go to do
speaker: Subject

text: in this year of famine and pestilence, have learned to keep my mind and ear cocked like a gun for the true poetry of the language to go off and fill the sky of the mind with angels conversing and have enough memory left to remember and write the angels down without pinning a single body or wing
speaker: Subject

text: I ((have)) finally returned to the cheerfulness I had when very young before the bubbles in my personal seltzer had gone flat when the fingers of school, having opened my thinking pat # {cough} having opened my thinking cap kept the bottle open long enough to let the fun out, amidst the multitude of others asking one way or another, Whatever happened to you? You were such a cheerful kid. And that I am.
speaker: Subject

speaker: Subject

text: An evening spent talking, spent thinking about what my life would be if I'd stayed with a particular girl or woman I went with, what would be if I'd have been accepted to and gone where I applied to a different school than the one I did, where I'd learn different social graces than the ones I have
speaker: Subject

text: where some of the material values of the American Dream had rubbed off enough to make me live it out in the good work sense
speaker: Subject

text: If I'd settled down and settled for the foundation on a house for future generations instead of assuming immediate # immediately past generations my foundation to mine. If I'd have been a little quicker to learn what was expected of me, and wanting to please pleased, going on that way through all eternity
speaker: Subject

text: I've probably been saved from mere routines by a streak of stubbornness, by a slow mind and tendency to drift
speaker: Subject

text: by an emotional development that requires my personal understanding before happening, feeling out the implications an emotion has in form of expectation, before trying out and after awareness
speaker: Subject

text: I sense a willingness to tell someone I know and like and sense the same from anything they'd like to know about me and at the same time have a vast sense of privacy, which means there's no way I'll wear out my personality and its sense of continuity, although sometimes I feel empty. But talking to someone I like and trust and sense the same from, I feel way up and after a long evening of talk about this and that, feel wide awake and feel the world wide and awake around me and have a visual intensity and memory that in near memory dulls and throbs and grows vivid as hell. When I bring it to mind some time from then what my life would've been like under different circumstances, ((it)) would've been different with its own attendant ifs and its own what might have been But this way I've elected to follow and cast my vote each waking day in I avoid the possibility of taking the past too seriously or feeling any bitterness or sadness
speaker: Subject

text: This way when my ship comes in I'll have passed out of mind beyond the sight of land and won't hesitate for a second to look back on all this with fondness or remiss
speaker: Subject

text: The air'll be clear, the moon'll be there, and you, whoever you are and hope to be will be here with my love
speaker: Subject

text: On a social level, the gradual assertion of the rights of individuals is determined in part by the value ((that)) the society places on the individual
speaker: Subject

text: This value not only determines what a society can do to protect the individual, but what contributions individuals can make to society
speaker: Subject

text: If all individuals are equal, are all individuals then equally expendable?
speaker: Subject

text: On the other hand, can an individual shed society and thereby transform it?
speaker: Subject

text: The determination of the value of protecting the individual is also fostered by the concept of genius. It may be that genius is fostered by a mutation of a society's ills with its strengths
